Historically, rapid long-end selloffs coincide with larger Nasdaq drawdowns; value/defensive exposures (e.g., Dow components) tend to hold up better, sometimes making new highs â€” a rotation from â€œlong duration growthâ€ to â€œshorter duration/valueâ€. Asymmetry-wise, Japanese equities are more sensitive to U.S. equities than vice versa.

5. Conclusions and Strategy

Section titled â€œ5. Conclusions and Strategyâ€

5.1 Key risks and scenarios

Section titled â€œ5.1 Key risks and scenariosâ€
  • Key risks: long-end UST yields grinding higher; structurally weaker DXY; valuation reset for high-growth tech.
  • Scenarios:
    • Base case: BOJ hikes in October, Fed on hold/turning dovish â†’ spreads narrow quickly; risks above materialize with higher intensity.
    • Delayed BOJ hike: BOJ waits â†’ pressure eases temporarily; structural risks remain, just pushed out.
    • Hawkish Fed: Fed re-hawks on inflation â†’ stronger USD and wider spreads, slowing the unwind of yen carry (contrary to current consensus).

5.2 Positioning and risk management

Section titled â€œ5.2 Positioning and risk managementâ€
  • U.S. Treasuries: Reduce long-duration exposure; hedge with futures/options; watch for curve steepening.
  • FX and USD: Position for DXY downside; consider tactical USD/JPY shorts to capture spread convergence.
  • Equities: Tactically underweight expensive, rate-sensitive growth; overweight value/defensive (staples, healthcare, stable dividends); selectively add Japanese beneficiaries (large banks, reasonably valued blue chips) for diversification.

item.title: Anthropic (Claude Codeâ€™s Parent) Completes $10B Funding Round: An Analysis
item.content:encoded:
Anthropic has emerged as a prominent player in artificial intelligence. Its core vision is to build AI systems that are trustworthy, interpretable, and controllableâ€”and to lead a â€œsafetyâ€‘first race.â€ Unlike many peers, Anthropicâ€™s story did not begin with a single technical breakthrough but with a deep philosophical and governance split. From day one, it has treated AI safety and ethics as a foundational mission, embedding them into the companyâ€™s legal structure, technical methodology, and commercial strategy.

Part I: Origins of a Safetyâ€‘First Mission

Section titled â€œPart I: Origins of a Safetyâ€‘First Missionâ€

Born of a split: OpenAIâ€™s philosophical rift

Section titled â€œBorn of a split: OpenAIâ€™s philosophical riftâ€

Anthropic was founded in 2021 by a group of former OpenAI employees, led by siblings Dario Amodei (former VP of Research at OpenAI) and Daniela Amodei (former VP of Safety and Policy). In late 2020, they left OpenAI with five colleagues due to fundamental disagreements over the companyâ€™s direction.

Dario and others were concerned about OpenAIâ€™s 2019 transition from a nonâ€‘profit to a â€œcappedâ€‘profitâ€ entity and its deep partnership with Microsoft. They believed this shift moved the mission from â€œbenefiting all of humanityâ€ toward commercialization and profit, relegating AI safety and ethics to a secondary role. As Dario put it, they â€œcould foresee the exponential growth of artificial intelligence,â€ and AI companies urgently needed â€œa set of values to constrain these powerful programs.â€ The founding of Anthropic was a direct counter to what they saw as sacrificing safety for commercial priorities.

Public benefit corporation: writing the mission into the charter

Section titled â€œPublic benefit corporation: writing the mission into the charterâ€

Anthropic is a Delaware public benefit corporation (PBC). This legal structure requires the company to balance shareholder interests with a publicâ€‘benefit purpose. For Anthropic, that purpose is to develop AI systems that are reliable, interpretable, and controllable.

To prevent commercial pressure from eroding its safety mission, Anthropic established the Longâ€‘Term Benefit Trust, which holds a special Tâ€‘class of shares and can elect a majority of the board. This governance design aims to legally insulate the safety missionâ€”at least in partâ€”from purely financial interests, addressing the limitations of traditional corporate governance in confronting potential catastrophic risks from AGI.

From the foundersâ€™ departures to the companyâ€™s structural design, Anthropicâ€™s core narrative is clear: rapid AI progress requires a missionâ€‘driven governance paradigm. This not only builds a â€œresponsibleâ€ brand but also offers a credible choice for those concerned about AGIâ€™s commercialization risks.

Part II: Claudeâ€™s Architectural Philosophy

Section titled â€œPart II: Claudeâ€™s Architectural Philosophyâ€

Anthropicâ€™s uniqueness lies not only in governance but in its technical methodology, centered on directly addressing the alignment problem.

Constitutional AI: encoding values

Section titled â€œConstitutional AI: encoding valuesâ€

Constitutional AI (CAI) aims to train AI to be â€œhelpful, honest, and harmless.â€ Its core idea is to introduce a humanâ€‘written â€œconstitutionâ€â€”a set of principles that guide the model to selfâ€‘critique and revise its outputs during training. Unlike the common approach of deflecting or blurring sensitive topics, CAI enables more direct responses under principled constraints and requires the model to explain refusals when appropriate.

Training occurs in two stages. In supervised fineâ€‘tuning, the model critiques and corrects its own problematic answers using constitutional principles, producing a â€œless harmfulâ€ dataset for further tuning.

Reinforcement learning from AI feedback (RLAIF): an engine for scalable alignment

Section titled â€œReinforcement learning from AI feedback (RLAIF): an engine for scalable alignmentâ€

The second stage uses reinforcement learning. Anthropic applies RLAIF: the model generates two candidate answers, then evaluates and selects a preferred one according to a randomly chosen constitutional principle; these judgments train a preference model so the final policy better adheres to the constitution.

Compared with the more common RLHF, Anthropic argues RLAIF is more efficient and scalable (less dependent on human labeling), improves interpretability and transparency by expressing goals in natural language, and somewhat reduces human bias. Critics note the constitution is still humanâ€‘written and thus subjective, and that reducing human intervention raises questions about accountability and oversight. The tension between â€œautomationâ€ and â€œhuman controlâ€ is central to understanding Anthropicâ€™s approach.

Part III: Evolution of the Claude AI Series

Section titled â€œPart III: Evolution of the Claude AI Seriesâ€

From research to frontier models: a fast timeline

Section titled â€œFrom research to frontier models: a fast timelineâ€

Since launching Claude 1 in March 2023, Anthropic has iterated rapidly on a roughly 4â€“8 month cadence: Claude 2 (July 2023), the Claude 3 family (March 2024), and beyondâ€”demonstrating that Anthropic is both a research organization and a product company competing at the frontier.

Each generation pushed forward on context length, reasoning, and multimodality: from Claude 2â€™s 100Kâ€‘token context window to Claude 3â€™s 200K, then toward ~1M tokens in extended reasoning modes with Claude 4. Starting with Claude 3, image+text is supported; coding, math, and logical reasoning improved markedly.

Tiered lineup: covering distinct use cases

Section titled â€œTiered lineup: covering distinct use casesâ€

Beginning with Claude 3, Anthropic adopted a threeâ€‘tier lineup:

  • Haiku: fastest, for realâ€‘time and lowâ€‘latency scenarios.
  • Sonnet: balanced performance/latency, for general tasks.
  • Opus: flagship, for complex tasks and advanced reasoning.

Claude 3.5 Sonnet (June 2024) surpassed the larger Claude 3 Opus on several benchmarks, signaling aggressive optimization and productization.

Early exploration of agentic capabilities

Section titled â€œEarly exploration of agentic capabilitiesâ€
  • Artifacts: introduced with Claude 3.5 Sonnet; generates and previews code, SVGs, websites, and more in a dedicated pane.
  • Computer Use: debuted in 3.5 Sonnet beta; the AI can operate a virtual desktop, simulating cursor, clicks, and input across applications for multiâ€‘step tasks.
  • Hybrid Dualâ€‘Mode Reasoning: added in Claude 3.7 and Claude 4; dynamically switches between fast responses and â€œextended thinking,â€ invoking tools (retrieval, code execution) when needed.

These capabilities move AI from assistantship toward autonomous agency, while bringing AGIâ€‘related risks closer to the real world.

Table 1: Release timeline and core capabilities of Claude

Section titled â€œTable 1: Release timeline and core capabilities of Claudeâ€
ModelRelease dateKey capabilities/notes
Claude 1Mar 2023Initial launch; assistant prototype
Claude 2Jul 2023Industryâ€‘leading 100Kâ€‘token context
Claude 3 family (Haiku, Sonnet, Opus)Mar 2024Tiered lineup; text+image; strong benchmarks
Claude 3.5 SonnetJun 2024Major gains in coding and chart analysis; introduced â€œArtifactsâ€
Claude 3.7 SonnetFeb 2025Hybrid reasoning; switch between fast/deep modes
Claude 4 family (Sonnet 4, Opus 4)May 2025~1Mâ€‘token context (extended reasoning); improved Computer Use and Working Notes

Part IV: Commercial Practice of Safe AI â€” Growth, Capital, and Partnerships

Section titled â€œPart IV: Commercial Practice of Safe AI â€” Growth, Capital, and Partnershipsâ€

Ascent in capital markets

Section titled â€œAscent in capital marketsâ€

Anthropicâ€™s valuation exceeded $61B by late 2024 and reached roughly $183B after its Series F in midâ€‘2025. The latest $13B round led by ICONIQ further strengthens its position across enterprise, developer, and premium consumer markets.

Revenue has grown rapidly as well: annualized runâ€‘rate rose from about $1B in early 2025 to over $5B by August. Claude Code alone reached more than a $0.5B annualized runâ€‘rate within three months, showing clear conversion from technology to competitive advantage.

Strategic alliances with tech giants

Section titled â€œStrategic alliances with tech giantsâ€

Anthropic forged deep partnerships with Amazon and Google: it designates AWS as a primary cloud provider and offers models on Amazon Bedrock; Google has also committed billions in investment and cloud infrastructure support. Access to compute such as Trainium and TPUs enables largeâ€‘scale frontier training.

Moral dilemma: lessons from a leaked memo

Section titled â€œMoral dilemma: lessons from a leaked memoâ€

In 2025, an internal memo by CEO Dario Amodei was leaked, candidly acknowledging that to remain competitive the company had considered seeking investment from Middle Eastern sovereign capitalâ€”and recognizing the â€œmoral risk.â€ He wrote: â€œI really wish we didnâ€™t have to be in this position, but we are,â€ and, â€œâ€˜No bad actor should benefit from our successâ€™ is a hard principle on which to run a business.â€

This highlights Anthropicâ€™s core contradiction: in a capitalâ€‘intensive race, even governance with publicâ€‘benefit features cannot fully escape the pressures of â€œracing to the bottom.â€

Table 2: Anthropicâ€™s major financing rounds and valuation

Section titled â€œTable 2: Anthropicâ€™s major financing rounds and valuationâ€

Sep/Oct 2023Amazon, GoogleAmazon committed $4B (first tranche $1.25B); Google committed $2B (first tranche $500M)>$61B
Mar 2024Amazon$2.75B (completing the $4B commitment)Not disclosed
Nov 2024Amazon$4B (total investment reached $8B)Not disclosed
May 2025ICONIQ, Fidelity, Lightspeed, etc.$13B~$183B

Part V: Outlook â€” AGI and Societal Impact

Section titled â€œPart V: Outlook â€” AGI and Societal Impactâ€

The AGI race: an urgent vision

Section titled â€œThe AGI race: an urgent visionâ€

Dario Amodei has expressed an aggressive timeline for AGI, even suggesting a â€œsingularityâ€ could arrive as early as 2026. This urgency helps explain Anthropicâ€™s immense capital needs and the difficult tradeâ€‘offs it faces in competition.

Leading a safetyâ€‘centric competition

Section titled â€œLeading a safetyâ€‘centric competitionâ€

Beyond setting a technical baseline with CAI, Anthropic actively participates in US AI policy discussions. Its collaboration with Palantir brought Claude 3/3.5 into â€œclassified environmentsâ€ for the first timeâ€”both validating capabilities and safety, and touching one of the modelâ€™s most controversial application domains.

AIâ€‘driven future: impact and challenges

Section titled â€œAIâ€‘driven future: impact and challengesâ€

Products like Claude Code make modern, automated software engineering a practical reality and will drive change across healthcare, education, and finance. Challenges remain: how to ensure systems apply ethical principles robustly in complex contexts; how to build regulatory and accountability frameworks; and how to rebuild public trust.

Conclusion: Anthropicâ€™s Inevitable Choice

Section titled â€œConclusion: Anthropicâ€™s Inevitable Choiceâ€

Anthropic began with a missionâ€‘driven split and embedded safety into its corporate DNA through a PBC and trustâ€‘based governance. Its rapid iteration and commercial growth suggest that a â€œsafety commitmentâ€ can be a powerful market differentiator. Yet the leaked memo reveals persistent tension between capital and ideals.

Building powerful AI and ensuring its safety are not parallel lines but two sides of the same coin. As Anthropic moves forward along this complicated path, it will shape the technical landscape of AI and force us to confront a deeper question: in an AIâ€‘driven world, how much principle are we willing to trade for power?

item.title: Claude Code vs Codex CLI â€” Which Fits Your Daily Dev?
item.content:encoded:
Claude Code is more mature for engineering workflows (subagents, slash commands, hooks). Codex (GPTâ€‘5 High) is faster, sticks closer to instructions, and gets things done with fewer words. Use both for maximum throughput.

Introduction

Section titled â€œIntroductionâ€

The community has been buzzing again about Codex CLI and Claude Code. Someone built a small tool using Cloudflare Workers + Telegram: it watches Codex GitHub releases and pushes new versions to Telegram. Both agents â€œworked endâ€‘toâ€‘endâ€, but the experience differed in meaningful ways.

Hereâ€™s a practical, readyâ€‘toâ€‘apply comparison to help you choose quickly.

TL;DR Checklist

Section titled â€œTL;DR Checklistâ€
  • Engineering/Extensibility: Claude Code wins. Subagents, custom slash commands, and hooks are very mature.
  • Execution rhythm/plan view: Codex shows more detail in its plan panel; Claude Code defaults to â€œcurrent task onlyâ€, which makes flow feel smoother.
  • Instruction adherence: Codex (GPTâ€‘5 High) followed explicit constraints (like directory layout) more strictly; in one run it emitted multiâ€‘file /src output, while Opus bundled code into a single worker.js.
  • Data fetching strategy: Different roads to Rome â€” Codex used Atom feeds; Claude Code used the GitHub API. Both got the job done.
  • Observability: Codex provides /status for token use and Ctrl+T to explore conversation history (community is adding export/persistence tooling).
  • Speed and cost perception: In a single task sample, GPTâ€‘5 used ~90k tokens vs Opus ~50k. Because GPTâ€‘5 is cheaper per token, total cost isnâ€™t necessarily higher. Treat this as an anecdote, not a benchmark.
  • Docs ecosystem: Claude Code docs feel more systematic; Codex docs are improving quickly.

Why Is Everyone Testing Right Now?

Section titled â€œWhy Is Everyone Testing Right Now?â€

OpenAI is positioning Codex as a fullâ€‘field development agent: CLI, IDE extensions, cloud, and GitHub integration in one. It shares state through your ChatGPT account so a task can bounce between local and cloud. The VS Code extension is live â€” no API key setup, plus cloud sandbox for execution.

The release cadence is fast, so media and community reviews are everywhere.

Headâ€‘toâ€‘Head: Findings from a Cloudflare Worker Field Test

Section titled â€œHeadâ€‘toâ€‘Head: Findings from a Cloudflare Worker Field Testâ€

1) Engineering Capability: Claude Code Feels Like an Orchestratable Platform

Section titled â€œ1) Engineering Capability: Claude Code Feels Like an Orchestratable Platformâ€
  • Subagents: Split roles and context with separate system prompts, tools, and isolated memory. Great for â€œdata gathering / solution review / scaffold generationâ€ assembly lines.
  • Slash commands: Expose MCPâ€‘discovered commands and build a teamâ€‘level action library inside your project.
  • Hooks: Force lifecycle actions (session start, before/after tool exec) to run every time. Think â€œlint â†’ test â†’ commitâ€ guaranteed, not subject to model mood.

Bottom line: If you need scale and control, Claude Codeâ€™s orchestration is a clear advantage.

2) Execution Experience: Codex Is Snappier; Claude Code Flows Nicely

Section titled â€œ2) Execution Experience: Codex Is Snappier; Claude Code Flows Nicelyâ€
  • Codex is concise, sticks closely to instructions, and moves fast.
  • Claude Codeâ€™s TUI is more mature; the diff views are clear. Defaulting to the current task reduces distractions from long plans.
  • In one run, Codex had â€œauto runâ€ selected but still asked for permissions fairly often; Claude Codeâ€™s interaction felt steadier.

3) Directory and Architecture Adherence: Codex â€œBuilds to Specâ€

Section titled â€œ3) Directory and Architecture Adherence: Codex â€œBuilds to Specâ€â€

Given the same project template and directory constraints:

  • Codex (GPTâ€‘5 High) produced multiâ€‘file output under /src.
  • Claude (Opus 4.1) consolidated into a single worker.js.

If you care a lot about rigid layouts, Codexâ€™s strictness is a plus.

4) Data Fetching Strategy: Two Valid Defaults

Section titled â€œ4) Data Fetching Strategy: Two Valid Defaultsâ€
  • Codex: prefer Atom feeds â€” conveniently structured.
  • Claude Code: call GitHub APIs â€” richer fields when you need them.

Both yielded what we needed for Telegram publishing; default â€œinfo densityâ€ differed slightly.

5) Observability and Review

Section titled â€œ5) Observability and Reviewâ€
  • /status to inspect token usage; Ctrl+T for conversation history. Community PRs aim to improve export and traceability.

What to Choose: Best Fit by Persona

Section titled â€œWhat to Choose: Best Fit by Personaâ€

You want to â€œShip Tonightâ€

Section titled â€œYou want to â€œShip Tonightâ€â€

Choose Codex:

  • Tighter instruction following, fewer pleasantries, default behavior that just works.
  • VS Code extension + cloud sandbox makes onboarding clean and fast.

You need â€œOrchestration, Governance, Reuseâ€

Section titled â€œYou need â€œOrchestration, Governance, Reuseâ€â€

Choose Claude Code:

  • Subagents for division of labor, slash commands to codify SOPs, hooks to harden workflows.
  • High reuse in teams; great for complex, multiâ€‘person projects.

You are â€œEfficiencyâ€‘maxâ€

Section titled â€œYou are â€œEfficiencyâ€‘maxâ€â€

Use both:

  • Codex to spin up features and validate ideas quickly.
  • Claude Code to codify process, hook into CI, and build a team command library.

One Page to Compare

Section titled â€œOne Page to Compareâ€
DimensionCodex (GPTâ€‘5 High)Claude Code (Opus 4.1 exemplar)
Timeâ€‘toâ€‘firstâ€‘shipFast, concise, gets things doneSlightly slower, steadier interaction
Instruction adherenceStrong (sticks to directory/constraints)Occasionally â€œhelpfulâ€ consolidation
EngineeringCLI + IDE + Cloud, improving fastSubagents / Slash / Hooks are mature
Observability/status, Ctrl+T, community tooling risingMature diffs, strong task focus
Data fetchingPrefers structured feeds (Atom)Prefers rich APIs (GitHub)
Docs ecosystemImproving quicklyMore systematic today

Note: this is based on public docs and a single real test. Details will change with updates.

Practical Workflow: Make It Your Daily Pipeline

Section titled â€œPractical Workflow: Make It Your Daily Pipelineâ€

Suggested pattern (copy freely):

  1. Use Codex to deliver the MVP: confirm interfaces, directories, and dependencies.
  2. Switch to Claude Code:
    • Create a â€œgathering subagentâ€ to pull context (docs, API constraints, dependency risks).
    • Add slash commands for common actions (/lint, /test, /gen-release-notes).
    • Configure hooks to enforce preâ€‘CI actions (preâ€‘commit checks, tests, semantic versioning, change set generation).
  3. Return to Codex for small iterative features and regression; keep an eye on tokens with /status.

Tip: Codexâ€™s brevity encourages quick iterations; Claude Codeâ€™s engineering primitives help turn wins into durable team assets.

Conclusion

Section titled â€œConclusionâ€

This isnâ€™t a â€œreplacementâ€ story. Codex is a sprinter; Claude Code is a triathlete. Use the right one for the job and youâ€™ll find they complement each other perfectly.

Which style do you prefer? Tell us â€” weâ€™ll keep this comparison updated as a living â€œselection guideâ€.

item.title: Microsoft CEOâ€™s 5 AI Prompts, Rebuilt for Real-World Workflows

In the past two days, Satya (Microsoft CEO) shared on X the 5 GPT-5/Copilot prompts he uses every day. Not flashy â€œdark magicâ€ â€” just practical, time-saving patterns. Multiple outlets summarized and relayed them.

â€”

Introduction

Section titled â€œIntroductionâ€

Anthropic is updating data policy for consumer products (including Claude, Pro, Max, and Claude Code when signed in with those accounts): you can choose whether chats and coding sessions are used for training; if you choose Allow, the retention period can be up to 5 years. â‘  Personal users (Free / Pro / Max)

â‘¡ Team / Enterprise / API (commercial products)

Local hardening you must do for Claude Code

  • The official recommendation is to use /bug to submit issues; it bundles context for Anthropic to diagnose. Therefore avoid it when dealing with sensitive repos/code.
  • The community has collected an env var to disable /bug (DISABLE_BUG_COMMAND=1). This is â€œunofficial / may changeâ€ â€” for reference only.

C. Local caches and session files

Section titled â€œC. Local caches and session filesâ€
  • Per official notes, the client can cache sessions locally for up to 30 days to aid resuming (configurable). In sensitive environments, regularly clean ~/.claude/ and set cache duration to a minimum.
  • The community has previously reported issues about .claude.json retaining conversation fragments â€” these are behavioral reports, not official guarantees. Add .claude/ to your security baseline and backup exclusion lists.

A â€œbeltâ€‘andâ€‘suspendersâ€ playbook (copy asâ€‘is)

Section titled â€œA â€œbeltâ€‘andâ€‘suspendersâ€ playbook (copy asâ€‘is)â€

Personal accounts (mustâ€‘do)

  2. Periodically clean ~/.claude/; before using /bug, do redaction/sanitization.
  3. Set: DISABLE_TELEMETRY=1, DISABLE_ERROR_REPORTING=1.

Teams/enterprises (strongly recommended)

  2. Inject the â€œnoâ€‘uploadâ€ env vars (Section A) centrally across servers and CI/CD.
  3. Prefer Bedrock/Vertex routes; implement cloudâ€‘side DLP/KMS and access auditing.

Common pitfalls to avoid

Section titled â€œCommon pitfalls to avoidâ€

  • Myth 1: â€œIf I delete historical chats, they wonâ€™t be used for training.â€ â†’ After deletion, they wonâ€™t be used for training, but whether they were trained on depends on your setting at the time; training is irreversible.

  • Myth 2: â€œUsing Claude Code equals enterpriseâ€‘grade protection.â€ â†’ It depends on the account and key you use. Claude Code signed in with a personal account is still under consumer terms.

  • Myth 3: â€œIf I go via Bedrock/Vertex, Iâ€™m done.â€ â†’ You still need to configure your own permission boundaries, key management, logging policies, and cache governance. The docs are explicit.

Closing

Section titled â€œClosingâ€

Data privacy has never been a simple on/off switch. Itâ€™s a set of habits: right configuration + right tools + team discipline. Work through the checklist above and your code and conversations will not be shared with Anthropic for training, while you also preserve your teamâ€™s compliance boundary.

Section titled â€œNVIDIAâ€™s P/E Paradox: A Deep Valuation Analysis Behind a Multiâ€‘Trillion Runâ€

At the peak of the global tech investment wave, NVIDIA stands out as the brightest star. Yet despite a market cap that has crossed $4T, its recent price action has puzzled many investors. The company delivered another quarter above Wall Street expectations, but the stock fell after hours and even flirted with a technical bear market. We look at the latest financials, trace valuation shifts over time, analyze the engines that power longâ€‘term growth and the risks that could slow it, and outline a forward view for the next decadeâ€”offering a clear, grounded perspective for everyday investors.

Why did the stock fall after an earnings beat?

Section titled â€œWhy did the stock fall after an earnings beat?â€

On the surface, NVIDIAâ€™s latest report was â€œpictureâ€‘perfect.â€ In FY26 Q2, total revenue reached $46.7B, up 56% year over year. GAAP net income rose 59% to $26.4B. When expectations are superâ€‘charged, even a small shortfall versus the most optimistic whispers can trigger disappointment.

In particular, investors fixated on the Data Center segment. Although it contributed 88% of total revenue ($41.1B) and grew strongly, it modestly missed the loftiest estimates, which some interpreted as a sign that nearâ€‘term growth may be bumping up against a ceiling. And while 56% y/y growth is extraordinary for almost any business, it was also NVIDIAâ€™s slowest growth rate in nine quarters since the AI upcycle began.

When a companyâ€™s bar moves from â€œgreatâ€ to â€œmythic,â€ even strong prints can disappoint. Shortâ€‘term price swings here reflect the marketâ€™s sensitivity to NVIDIAâ€™s forward growth trajectory.

P/E is the simplest yardstick for what investors are willing to pay today for one dollar of a companyâ€™s earnings. Highâ€‘growth companies command higher P/Es, reflecting expectations for sustained, superior earnings expansion.

NVIDIAâ€™s P/E evolution broadly falls into three phases:

  • Phase 1 (Preâ€‘AI boom): Before the generative AI surge, NVIDIA traded around 20â€“60x P/E, supported by strong gaming and cryptocurrency cycles.

This shift suggests a transition from a company priced mainly on narrative to one anchored in durable profitabilityâ€”a â€œtech blue chip.â€ Investors should expect fewer sudden multiple expansions and more return driven by steady earnings growth.
